#Text=Cullera
#Text=Cullera
#Text=is a coastal city in Valencia .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Cullera has been inhabited since Neolithic times , as attested by a large number of remains and archaeological sites in the area .
#Text=In modern times the city is known for its gastronomy and for its burgeoning tourism sector , and serves as a popular getaway for both domestic and foreign visitors .
#Text=Tourist Info Cullera Centro
#Text=, C/ del Mar , 93 , ☏ +34961720974 , fax : +34961738062 , ✉ cullera@touristinfo.net .
#Text=Cullera 's primary tourist office .
#Text=Tourist Info Cullera Playa
#Text=, Plaza Constitución , s/n ( Playa San Antonio ) , ☏ +34961731586 , ✉ culleraplaya@touristinfo.net .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Valencia has the closest airport , at 40 km away .
#Text=By train
#Text=Estación de Tren de Cullera
#Text=( Cullera Train Station ) , Carretera Sueca , s/n , ☏ +34902240202 .
#Text=From Valencia , Renfe regional train line C1 connects Cullera with Estació de València Nord and Gandía .
#Text=Trains depart hourly and the journey from Valencia lasts 34 minutes .
#Text=By bus
#Text=Alsa
#Text=operates a route connecting all major coastal settlements between Valencia and Alicante , including Cullera , Gandía , Oliva , Dénia , Calpe , Altea , Benidorm , and Villajoyosa .
#Text=Buses stop at .
#Text=Get around
#Text=Autocares Ribera
#Text=( tel .
#Text=+34 961 721 012 ) operates a circular bus route between the city and beaches ; a schedule is available here .
#Text=See
#Text=Castell de Cullera
#Text=( Castillo de Cullera / Cullera Castle ) , ☏ +34961732643 , ✉ guia_museus@cullera.es .
#Text=Built by the Moors in the 10th century , the castle was taken in 1239 by King Jaime I of Aragon .

#Text=In the 16th century it played an important role in the defense of the city against Barbary pirates , and saw action again in the 19th century during the Spanish War of Independence and the Carlist Wars .
#Text=The castle has been fully restored , and offers great views of the bay , the mouth of the Júcar River , and the region .
#Text=The castle can be accessed by the Camino del Calvario ( ' Way of the Calvary ' ) , a steep footpath which zigzags up the side of the mountain and has 14 stations of the cross .
#Text=Santuario de la Virgen del Castillo
#Text=( Sanctuary of the Virgin of the Castle ) ( immediately adjacent to the Castell ) .
#Text=This neo-Byzantine chapel was built at the end of the 19th century , and is dedicated to Cullera ’s patron saint , the ‘ Mare de Deu del Castell ’ .
#Text=Especially noteworthy inside is a 14th-century Gothic painting of the Madonna .
#Text=Torre de Santa Ana
#Text=( Tower of Santa Ana ) .
#Text=Feb-Jun : Th - Su and holidays 10:00 - 13:30 ; Jul-Sep : Tu - Su 10:30 - 13:00 18:30 - 20:30 ; Oct-Jan :
#Text=Sa Su and holidays 10:00 - 13:30 .

#Text=Also known as Torre de la Reina Mora ( ' Tower of the Moorish Queen ' ) , this 13th-century tower was originally part of the defensive perimeter for the Moorish castle and served as part of the main gate .
#Text=It was heavily modified in the 16th century to defend against Barbary pirates , but the structure has since been restored to its original design .
#Text=Inside there is now an exhibit devoted to the history of the tower and the castle .
#Text=El Fort
#Text=( Fuerte Carlista / Carlist Fortress ) , Pla dels Pics ( accessed by footpath from the castle ) .
#Text=Two ruined fortifications from the first Carlist War , which were built atop a Moorish citadel .
#Text=At 210m above sea level , great views can be had from this spot .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Museu Cova del Dragut
#Text=( Museo Cueva de Dragut / Cave-Museum of Dragut ) , Plaça Doctor Fleming , s/n ( Faro de Cullera ) , ☏ +34961746700 , ✉ contacto@cuevadeldragut.com .
#Text=Oct-May daily 11:00 - 14:30 16:00 - 21:00 ; Jun-Sep daily 09:00 - 14:00 .
#Text=In 1550 , Dragut , a close associate of the dreaded pirate Barbarossa , attacked and laid waste to Cullera , after which the town was virtually abandoned for several decades .

#Text=According to legend this cave was the site of a prisoner exchange during the siege , and is now used as a museum devoted to Mediterranean piracy in the 16th century . € 5 ( adults ) , € 3 ( children ) .
#Text=Torre del Marenyet
#Text=( Marenyet Tower ) , ☏ +34961732643 .
#Text=Oct-Jan : Sa Su and holidays 10:00 - 13:30 ; Feb-Jun : Tu - Su and holidays 10:00 - 13:30 , Jun-Sep : Tu - Su 10:30 - 13:00 18:30 - 20:30 .
#Text=This watchtower was built in 1577 as part of a coastal network of watchtowers used to defend against Barbary pirates , following the devastation brought on Cullera by Dragut in 1550 .
#Text=It now has a number of displays demonstrating the use of the watchtower and illustrating the problem of piracy in the 16th century .
#Text=Refugio Museo de la Guerra Civil
#Text=, Plaça de la Verge , s/n ( beneath the Mercado Municipal ) , ☏ +34961732643 .
#Text=Guided tours on Th Sa Su 10:00 - 14:00 .
#Text=This bomb shelter was built by Republicans during the Spanish Civil War .
#Text=It was never completed or used , but has been fully restored and has displays on life during the war .
#Text=It is open to the public by guided tours which last between 20-30 minutes . € 1 .
#Text=Barri del Pou
#Text=( Barrio del Pozo ) ( E of the Mercado Municipal and S of the Torre de Santa Ana ) .

#Text=This charming neighbourhood with whitewashed houses marks the location of the original Arab settlement of Qulayra , and the layout of narrow streets remains practically unchanged since that time .
#Text=Botánic Cullera
#Text=( Jardin Botánico / Botanic Gardens ) , Crta Nazaret-Oliva , km 27 , ☏ +34637482548 , fax : +34961118629 , ✉ botanic.cullera@gmail.com .
#Text=The gardens have more than 2,500 plant species .
#Text=Also on the grounds is a restored 19th-century farmhouse , now used for a small ethnological museum to display traditional farming tools .
#Text=€ 2 ( adults ) .
#Text=Beaches
#Text=Cullera has over 15km of sandy beaches .
#Text=( Playa de San Antonio ) is the most urban beach , while ( Playa del Racó ) is somewhat more sedate ; both beaches have loungers for rent as well as snack bars and restaurants .
#Text=( Playa Cap Blanc ) is well-suited for wind-surfing , while ( Playa de los Olivos ) is good for families .
#Text=The small cove of ( Playa del Faro / Lighthouse Beach ) is good for diving , while dogs are permitted at the more isolated ( Playa de la Escollera / Breakwater Beach ) .

#Text=In July and August these beaches all have disabled access with lifeguards , toilets and foot-washing stations , and first-aid stations , except for Platja de l'Escullera which has no disabled access .
